pull_request: Refactoring the API calls In the process of refactoring related to the networking stack, I introduced a class ApacheHttpClientMediaWikiApi and felt the need to at least smoke test a few API calls to make sure that requests and responses are correctly handled. I used the MockWebServer (from OkHttp) to serve up canned responses and assert that requests are well formed at a unit-test level. This was already a transitive dependency from the mapbox library, made explicit in the build.gradle file. My refactor pulls all of the API calls into a single place so that the body of the app depends on a MediaWikiApi interface returning application specific models, with a concrete ApacheHttpClientMediaWikiApi class that hides the implementation. This makes the code more testable (isolating the networking tests to a single class) and makes it easier to use mocks in the rest of the app if you want to unit test just the interactions later. Although the testing isn't yet complete, I wanted to get the code into your hands as (IMO) it forms a solid basis to address your high-priority item #705 (upload tests). This PR doesn't include those tests, but it does aim to set you up for success in this endeavor. :) issue_#705: Implement upload tests As suggested by @tobias47n9e after the 2.4 upload crash fiasco. We probably need lots of other tests too, but these ones should be a higher priority IMO.

pull_request: Detecting pictures that are too dark As discussed in #74, this attempts to detect 2 kinds of unwanted pictures: 1-Images that are too dark 2-Images that are blurry. When the app detects an image which it finds to be too dark or blurry it shows a popup with an error message. The popup is basically a warning since the user can choose to ignore it and continue uploading the image. As for the image processing part, detecting images that are too dark works quite flawlessly as per my testing. I have never come across an image that was pointed out as being too dark incorrectly or vice versa. On the other hand, while blurry images detection works well enough, the results become less consistent for images taken during the night and/or in poor lighting. It isn't that it fails every time, just that every now and then you will run into an image which looks sharp but was marked as blurry by the app. I have tweaked and played with the configuration quite a lot with the current setup working best for me. However I am not completely convinced. That said, having worked on it for quite a while, I felt best to put the code out for others to see. Maybe having some fresh eyes could lead to changes/improvements. P.S: I have added the OpenCV library to the repository as part of this pull request. However I found this gitignore file that suggests excluding the library from the repository. This will need to be discussed. Also we will definitely need to add a section in the Wiki about setting up OpenCV. issue_#74: Detect joke/unwanted pictures Like the traditional Commons upload, this app is subject to "vandalism", which in this case is not destructive, but uploading pictures that are not meant to illustrate wiki sites, but only as inside-jokes, to repulse viewers, or as a result of total boredom. Non-exhaustive list of subjects that might not be wanted: The difficult thing is to save Commons volunteers' time while not establishing our own censorship either. Maybe "tagging" such pictures with a particular category? Thanks Justin for the idea!

pull_request: Bug#954 Take latitude/longitude from picture taken seconds after Fixes bug #954 issue_#954: Take latitude/longitude from picture taken seconds after When I go photohunting and finally reach that historical remain after walking for kilometers, I usually take several pictures with slightly different lighting/angle. I usually take about 5 pictures of the thing, and when I am back home I judge which one is the best. Problem: The first few pictures usually do not have GPS information. And quite often the first picture is the best. Actually, when uploading from Android I usually have the gallery app showing each picture fullscreen, and I swipe in chronological order, so the one which I upload to Commons is usually the first I took, often without GPS info. Solution: When the user tries to upload a picture with GPS info, try to find a picture taken within 20 seconds after which has GPS info. Then show a screen showing the two picture and asking "Did you shoot these two pictures at the same place? Do you want to use the latitude/longitude of the picture on the right? And use it. Do not use GPS orientation as orientation can totally change within a second. The worst error would probably be someone taking serial shoots from a running high-speed train, that's why the confirmation step is required. Technically that could be done by reading the chosen picture's file creation date and folder, then listing the files in that folder by creation date, and reading the EXIF of the ones after until either you find GPS coordinates or the EXIF has more than 10 seconds. A "phase 2" enhancement could be getting the EXIF's GPSDOP parameter (measurement precision) to use the one with the best precision, as GPS sometimes takes a bit of time to get precise.

pull_request: issue #1130 -(j). bad Token Exception from showDialog() in ExistingFiâ€¦ For #1130 (j), the exception occurs when app tries to open a dialog from ExistingFileAsync (extends AsyncTaskin) in this case. To fix, we can check if parent activity (the share activity in this case) is still running and show dialog only when it's finished. To get parent activity into the ExistingFileAsync class, we can pass it as a parameter. But, this will cause memory leaks when task is complete. Solution is to use WeakReference to let the Garbage collector know. I also changed context to be a weakReference. Best issue_#1130: Crashes in v2.6.7 New contributors welcome - please mention the specific issue you are fixing (e.g. 1130(a)) in your pull request.

pull_request: Remove current location retrieval from upload process entirely Temporary fix for #1599 . We are concerned that people who enabled the "automatically get current location" setting prior to the subtext change may not realize that their location is being added to the image's location template. This removes current location retrieval entirely from the upload process, and removes the Setting as well. Where possible, I have left methods intact so that in the future if we decide to reimplement this (retrieving current location solely for category suggestions but not adding it to the template), we will not need to rewrite code. However, I have removed most of the method calls, and methods that would affect the user (e.g. the snackbar requesting location permissions). As an added bonus, this should fix #1515 since the LocationListener will not be registered in ShareActivity. Tested on Nexus S emulator running API 25 on betaDebug. pull_request: Feature/permissions library Fixes {App doesnot ask for permission when multiple pics are shared ISSUE #1697 } Fixes #{GitHub issue number and } {Describe the changes made and why they were made.} Added a library Dexter to handle runtime permissions more efficiently (Note by @misaochan: This has been discussed and approved at #1773 ). Also, in MultipleShareActivity, the following changes were made Behaviour changes : When user tries to share(upload) images to commons via MultipleShareActivity, following decision tree is followed a. If the app has permission for external storage, normal upload operation is followed b. If the app does not has the permission for external storage, dexter is used to ask for the same c. If the user gives us the required permission, normal upload flow is proceeded d. If the doesnot gives us the required permission a rationale dialog is shown with the appropriate message to let him know why we need the permission e. If he presses okay, steps a-c are followed and if he presses cancel, we close the app. f. If while asking for permission, the user chooses never ask again, then next time he tries to upload an image via MSA, the rational dialog follows the app setting screen where he could manually give us the required permission and the onActivityResult of same is handled Tested on {27 & name of samsung s7 }, with {build variant, ProdDebug}. issue_#1697: App doesnot ask for permission when multiple pics are shared [Summary:] App doesnot ask for storage permission when multiple pics are shared through gallery. [Steps to reproduce:] 1.Select pics you want to share through any gallery. 2.Click on the share button. 3.Select the commons app from the recommended app list. 4.The dialogue box which should appear asking for storage permission doesnot appear. issue_#1773: Use a library for checking various permissions [Summary:] Our app asks for runtime permissions in various places and in the past we have run into several issues/crashes because of missing permissions checks. The process of ensuring that permission is granted is cumbersome: Making sure that all these steps are followed correctly is a tedious task. It might be fruitful if we start using a 3rd party library for checking and handling permissions. I have tried out these two libraries in the past and found both of them to be quite useful. pull_request: Remove dependency on Glide, Picasso, SVG, and multidex. This removes the dependency on Glide, as well as the SVG rendering library, whose only purpose was to display a single SVG image in the Notification activity. Unfortunately Android doesn't support SVG natively, but Echo notifications have icons that are SVG formatted. Rather than import a bunch of heavy libraries to support this single case of SVG rendering, we can simply create a few local drawables that correspond to the different types of notifications, and use them instead. This also removes the (single) use of the Picasso library, and replaces it with correct usage of Fresco. And because so much bloat has been removed, we can also now remove multidex, since the method count is now well under 65k, and is back in the real world.

pull_request: Add geocoding template Implement #35 issue_#35: Automatically add Commons Geocoding Template from the GPS data stored in image The MediaWiki API only finds images that have been explicitly geocoded, i.e. the Locations template added to the Commons page. This hampers categorization of future uploaded pics with similar coordinates, as the newly-implemented GPS categorization depends on finding nearby pictures.
